channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: What We Know About the Suspect in the Brown and M.I.T. Killings
item.description: Officials identified a man from Portugal as the suspect in the deadly shooting at Brown University and the killing of an M.I.T. professor. The police said on Thursday he died from a self-inflicted gunshot.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers outside a storage facility on Hampshire Road in Salem, N.H., on Thursday night.

item.title: A Reddit Post Led to a Breakthrough in the Brown Shooting Investigation
item.description: A Reddit user provided information that helped identify Claudio Manuel Neves Valente as not only the suspect in the campus shooting, but also the murder of an M.I.T. professor.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn and Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle is loaded onto a tow truck outside the storage facility in Salem, N.H., where the Brown University shooting suspect’s body was found on Thursday.

item.title: Europe to Lend $105 Billion to Ukraine, Without Touching Russian Funds
item.description: European Union officials wanted to use Russia’s frozen assets to back a major loan to Ukraine. Facing opposition in their own camp, they settled on another way.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Geert Vanden Wijngaert/Associated Press
item.media:description: Antonio Costa, center, president of the European Council, said at a news conference early Friday in Brussels that the newly reached deal would “address the urgent financial needs of Ukraine.”

item.title: Putin’s Year-End News Conference Set for Friday
item.description: The annual news conference sets the Kremlin’s tone for the next year and highlights President Vladimir V. Putin’s grip over Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Ramil Sitdikov/Reuters
item.media:description: A digital screen in Moscow promoting President Vladimir V. Putin’s year-end televised phone-in and news conference.

item.title: Judge Convicted of Obstructing Agents as They Sought Undocumented Immigrant
item.description: The Wisconsin state judge, Hannah C. Dugan, was accused of ushering a man to a side door as federal agents waited outside a courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Sara Stathas/Reuters
item.media:description: Judge Hannah C. Dugan entered court on the first day of her federal trial.

item.title: Takeaways From the Trial of Wisconsin Judge Hannah Dugan
item.description: The Milwaukee judge was charged with obstructing federal immigration agents, who were trying to arrest a man who had appeared before her on a battery charge.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Sara Stathas/Reuters
item.media:description: Judge Hannah C. Dugan, right, outside the federal courthouse in Milwaukee earlier this week.

item.title: Kennedy Center Board Moves to Rename It the Trump-Kennedy Center
item.description: The board for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced that it would now be named the Trump-Kennedy Center, although a formal change may have to be approved by Congress.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was so named by law.

item.title: Trump Administration to Appeal Harvard Funding Case
item.description: Facing a deadline to appeal, the Justice Department told the courts late Thursday that it would try to overturn a judge’s ruling in favor of Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Trump Signs Order to Ease Restrictions on Marijuana
item.description: Marijuana’s classification as one of the most dangerous and habit-forming substances has long drawn criticism.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Ashley Southall
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said the move would allow for more research to be done with cannabis.

item.title: Trump Announces $1,776 ‘Warrior Dividend’ for Military
item.description: President Trump promised active duty troops a $1,776 check, citing increased revenue raised by tariffs, but the funding is coming from money for the military included in this year’s domestic spending law.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Ali Watkins
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. service members at Fort Bragg, N.C., in June.

item.title: ‘A Singularly Turbulent Time’: Deeper Uncertainty in Store for Global Economy
item.description: A reordering of the rules of trade, set on top of transformational change in technology, demographics and climate, is remaking jobs, politics and lives.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: A furniture factory in Vietnam. Chinese exports are surging not just into Europe but even more sharply into Southeast Asia.

item.title: Bank of Japan Raises Interest Rates to Highest Level in 30 Years
item.description: The Bank of Japan moved to slow inflation as the prime minister is borrowing more to fund an ambitious effort to build up industry and support households.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The rate increase is widely viewed as an attempt to ultimately help cool inflation and give wages a chance to keep up.

item.title: ‘Don’s Best Friend’: How Epstein and Trump Bonded Over the Pursuit of Women
item.description: The president has tried to minimize their friendship, but documents and interviews reveal an intense and complicated relationship. Chasing women was a game of ego and dominance. Female bodies were currency.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore and Julie Tate
item.category: Trump Plaza Hotel & Casino (Atlantic City, NJ)

item.title: Britain Is Preparing for Attacks on Its Soil. Critics Say It Must Move Faster.
item.description: As military officials sound the alarm over Russian hybrid attacks, the chair of Parliament’s defense committee said the government’s progress on ramping up home defense was “glacial.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Andrei Pungovschi/Getty Images
item.media:description: British soldiers during an exercise in Smardan, Romania, in February. In June, the British government published a strategic defense review that said the country must move to “war-fighting readiness.”

item.title: Rob Reiner Family Tragedy Strikes a Nerve for Families Fighting Addiction
item.description: Nick Reiner, charged with murdering his parents, Rob and Michele Singer Reiner, spent much of his life battling drug addiction, an affliction that millions of Americans face.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Constanza Hevia H. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pattie Vargas’s daughter and son both struggled with addiction. “As a parent, I would have cut off both my arms to save my kids,” she said.

item.title: After Rob Reiner’s ‘North’ Flopped, He Proved He Could Take Criticism With Humor
item.description: Roger Ebert said he “hated, hated, hated, hated, hated” Reiner’s 1994 film “North.” The director took it in stride.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Andy Schwartz/Fotos International, Getty Images
item.media:description: Rob Reiner on the set of “North” in 1994. The movie was released on the heels of several hit movies he had directed.

item.title: Mamdani Appointee Resigns After Decade-Old Antisemitic Posts Re-emerge
item.description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa resigned from her just-announced post as Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s director of appointments after the Anti-Defamation League resurfaced the comments.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa resigned from her new post a day after it was announced, apologizing for her remarks and for becoming a distraction from the transition’s work.

item.title: Australia Announces Plan to Buy Back Guns in Wake of Bondi Attack
item.description: The program is expected to take hundreds of thousands of firearms out of circulation, the prime minister said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Hilary Wardhaugh/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, right, at a news conference in Canberra, Australia, on Friday. He announced a nationwide gun buyback plan on the heels of a deadly mass shooting in Sydney last weekend.

item.title: How Did a City of 10 Million People Nearly Run Out of Water?
item.description: Restricting Tehran’s growth and water use — however politically difficult — would be more prudent than trying to engineer ever more elaborate workarounds.
item.dc:creator: Peter Frankopan

item.title: Justin Trudeau and Katy Perry Are Worth Rooting For
item.description: As a politician, Justin Trudeau was an excellent celebrity. And the rest of the world could learn a useful lesson from how he wielded his star power.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Marche
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez/The New York Times

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene, Donald Trump Jr. and More Conservative Figures Announce Their Engagements
item.description: Several prominent conservative figures have announced that they are engaged this week, news often celebrated by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. confirmed his engagement this week to Bettina Anderson, a Florida influencer and Palm Beach socialite.

item.title: Several Billion Dollars Were Lost to Fraud in Minnesota, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Federal prosecutors said they were now investigating fraud worth billions of dollars in 14 social services programs in the state.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents executed a search warrant as part of a fraud investigation in Minnesota.

item.title: Palo Alto Confronts Billionaires Over Their Housing Compounds
item.description: The Silicon Valley college town has changed drastically as Mark Zuckerberg, Larry Page and other tech founders have scooped up multiple properties.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: The D.N.C. Is Scrapping Its Report on What Went Wrong in 2024
item.description: Ken Martin, the Democratic National Committee chairman, ordered the autopsy months ago but is now said to believe that its release would be counterproductive for the party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Here’s our North Star: Does this help us win?” Ken Martin, the Democratic National Committee chairman, said in a statement about the 2024 audit. “If the answer is no, it’s a distraction from the core mission.”
